repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone  - Bumbuna Hydroelectric
            Environmental and Social Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Bumbuna Hydroelectric
            Environmental and Social Management Project for Sierra Leone
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory,
            the risk to development outcome was high, the Bank
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the measures necessary for environmental
            and social safeguards compliance were revised and extended
            several times during project implementation. Many of the
            revisions were initiated by the two panels of experts. For
            instance, the size of the environmental offset was revised
            upwards, including the addition of the Loma Mountain
            National Park. The number of people to be compensated under
            the resettlement action plan, or RAP also was revised during
            project implementation. The installation of a siren system
            was added when the recruitment of an experienced operator
            did not take place in time. While adjusting the social and
            environmental activities to changing circumstances is
            sometimes necessary, the scope and frequency of revisions is
            notable. The Bank's environmental and social safeguards
            policies apply to the entirety of an infrastructure project
            supported by the Bank and its associated facilities,
            regardless of the extent of Bank support. In the case of the
            Bumbuna project, most construction activities already had
            been completed when International Development Association,
            or IDA financing became effective. The project tried to
            retrofit good performance on a hydropower development that
            was already near completion. As the Bank was not financing
            construction, it had no formal relationship with the
            contractor. Given the frequent power outages in Sierra
            Leone, the GoSL's interest was mainly on commissioning
            BHP as soon as possible. After project restructuring, the
            operation exclusively supported environmental and social activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Bumbuna Hydroelectric
            Environmental and Social Management Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sierra Leone Hydro Electric Project
            had been developed to provide electricity to the Western
            Area of Freetown and some major towns along the transmission
            Line. Compensation for the loss of property, land, house
            crops etc., is in consonance with the World Bank operational
            policy O.P 4:12 on in voluntary relocation and resettlement.
            Project affected peoples' (PAPs) who had been
            identified during the census stage of the update were to
            benefit from compensations of moving and transition
            allowances. This is not however a compensation per-sae, for
            the loss of property, but rather a means to enhance
            households to transport their belongings from their previous
            settlements to new locations. To some households, the moving
            and transition allowances served as 'seed money'
            for starting a small business. Additionally in kind
            compensation of a hundred acre land has been provided by the
            Ministry of Lands and Country Planning as a resettlement
            site for PAPs who are asset owners and who had lost their
            properties to the project. PAPS were issued identification
            cards and reference code numbers according to their
            categories. A total number of 1,579 respondents were
            recorded as eligible recipients of the moving transition
            allowances. The Sierra Leone Commercial Bank was contracted
            to make direct payments to all PAPS.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Bumbuna Hydroelectric
            Environmental and Social Management Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Bumbuna
            Hydroelectric Environmental and Social Management Project is
            to assist the recipient in satisfactorily addressing and
            mitigating the environmental and social impacts in the
            project area associated with the completion and initial
            operation of the Bumbuna hydroelectric dam and transmission
            line. The restructuring will affect neither project outcomes
            nor project development objectives and the project's
            scope, results framework and outputs will remain unchanged.
            The restructuring is comprised of two changes: a)
            reallocation of additional grant resources of SDR 6.3
            million among different expenditure categories to allow for
            the supply, installation, commissioning and testing of
            sirens, which was not envisaged in 2010; and b) extension of
            the project closing date by nine months from September 30,
            2012, to June 30, 2013 to allow for the remaining activities
            to be completed. Further, the extension of the project
            closing date will also allow the Bank to engage with the
            Government of Sierra Leone to discuss and agree on a
            sustainable mechanism under the broader energy-sector
            dialogue to finance the Bumbuna safety, environmental and
            social management measures.

display_title.display_title:
Sierra Leone - Bumbuna
            Hydroelectric Environmental and Social Management Project :
            restructuring : Main report
